items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the current bid limit of $84,100 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.

items.item_details:
Board Policy 7080.203 defines Class III records as, including but not limited to, detailed records relating to:  records basic to an audit, including those relating to attendance, average daily attendance, or a business or financial transaction (purchase orders, invoices, warrants, ledger sheets, canceled checks and subs, student body and cafeteria records, etc.), and detailed records used in the preparation of any other report.
	 
Board Policy 7080.204 states that Class III records basic to an audit shall not be destroyed until after the third July 1st succeeding the completion of the audit required by Education Code 84040 or of any other legally required audit, or after the ending date of any retention period required by any agency other than the State of California, whichever date is later.
	 
The Bookstores have the following Class III records that meet the criteria for destruction:
	 
Parking Permit Logs through FY 2009-2010
Online Order Logs through FY 2009-2010
Month-End Reports through FY 2009-2010
Paid Returned Checks through FY 2009-2010
Accounts Payable Records through FY 2009-2010
Financial Statements through FY 2009-2010
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the destruction of records listed per Section 7080.203 of the Retention and destruction of Records under Board policies.

items.item_details:
The continuation of the Student Support Services Program was made possible by a federal TRIO program grant awarded to Evergreen Valley College on September 1, 2010.  This is the final year of a five-year grant for the period September 1, 2014 - August 31, 2015.
	 
The target populations of this grant are students who are first generation, low income and/or have a physical or learning disability.  The program's goals are to increase retention, increase graduation rates and facilitate transfer to a baccalaureate degree granting college or university.

items.item_details:
California Community College Chancellor’s Office (CCCCO) to allocate funding for two-year planning and implementation grants with the purpose of developing regional plans to better serve the educational needs of adults. Assembly Bill 86 (AB 86) outlines expectations for consortium development as well as planning and implementation requirements to establish the Adult Education Consortium Program. The central intent of AB 86 is to expand and improve the provision of adult education, via these consortia, with incremental investments starting with the 2015-16 fiscal year.
	 
Of that $25 million, $657,493 has been awarded to South Bay Consortium for Adult Education (SBCAE) that consists of the following member institutions:
San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (San Jose City College, Evergreen Valley College)
West Valley-Mission Community College District (West Valley College, Mission College)
San Jose Unified School District (Silicon Valley Adult Education)
Milpitas Unified School District (Milpitas Adult Education, including Santa Clara County Correctional Facilities)
East Side Union High School District (East Side Adult Education)
Campbell Union High School District (Campbell Adult and Community Education)
Santa Clara Unified School District (Santa Clara Adult Education)
	 
SBCAE covers the geographical boundaries of both San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) and West Valley Mission Community College District (WVMCCD).  
	 
To prepare adult learners for college, career, and civic responsibility, the SBCAE will address the following program areas by 2015:
Elementary and secondary basic skills, including classes required for a high school diploma or high school equivalency certificate
Classes and courses for immigrants eligible for education services in citizenship and English as a second language and workforce preparation classes in basic skills
Education programs for adults with disabilities
Short-term career technical education programs with high employment potential
Programs for apprentices 
	 
By 2015-16, depending upon available funding, the SJECCD and its network educational institutions will offer
Credit, enhanced credit, and non-credit programs and courses for adults
Seamless educational pathways for students to earn college certificates and degrees and/or prepare for workforce
Accelerated educational and/or workforce preparation programs for those who are balancing work, family, and other responsibilities
Workforce programs leading to employment opportunities that support the local economy 
	 
WestEd will be providing “Research Consultant” services to aid in the completion of the regional plan and required documentation SBCAE must present to the California Department of Education and the California Community College Chancellor’s Office.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve an independent contract for $75,350 for WestED. The contractor will provide services for South Bay Consortium for Adult Education (SBCAE), for which SJECCD is fiscal agent.
items.item_text: Approval of WestEd Independent Contract for AB86 Planning Grant
items.item_text_raw: 14. Approval of WestEd Independent Contract for AB86 Planning Grant

items.item_details:
Following approval by the Board of Trustees on December 13, 2011, the District entered into a one-year agreement with A. Plescia & Co. in the amount of $75,000 effective January 19, 2012 to provide consulting services related to the planned development of the land adjacent to the Evergreen Valley College campus.  The agreement was extended an additional year beginning January 19, 2013, and a $20,000 increase was approved by the Board of Trustees July 9, 2013.  An amendment approved by the Board of Trustees on February 11, 2014 extended the term to January 17, 2015 with an increase of $18,000.  
	 
The attached Amendment #3 is to cover additional costs related to Task 3, over and above the work items set forth in the approved Scope of Work, and to provide adequate funding to complete Task 4 and Task 5.  The additional Task 3 costs are related to the District’s process for review, evaluation, and analysis of the proposals submitted to the District, including participation in additional meetings and preparation of District staff recommendations for review and consideration by the Board of Trustees, as well as attendance at additional meetings of the Board of Trustees.
	 
Upon approval by the Board of Trustees, the agreement with A. Plescia and Co. will be increased by $17,000 for a total of $130,000.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Amendment #3 to the agreement with A. Plescia & Co., an independent contractor providing consulting services related to land development, increasing the amount by $17,000 for a total of $130,000.

items.item_details:
On October 8, 2013 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with XL Construction, to provide design-build services for the District Office Renovation Project located at 40 S. Market Street. Construction projects often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order. During the Design phase and initial inspection of the building, items were re-evaluated for long and near term value to the District. This process precipitated changes to the design as well as to the design-build agreement and subsequent change requests from XL Construction. These change requests were reviewed for accuracy and conformance with the contract documents.
	 
Original Contract Amount        $6,100,000

items.item_details:
San Jose City College is engaging in a campus wide project to improve the overall health and safety of their urban forest.  The project includes trimming, pruning and the removal of certain trees based on the recommendation of a certified arborist.  There are also twelve (12) new trees being installed as part of this project in one of the prominent pathways following the removal of the hazardous trees.
	 
Hort Science, a certified arborist, was engaged to update the existing SJCC campus tree survey and inventory and to identify trees that were in need of special attention as well as trees that were sick, dead, inappropriate for their location, or otherwise creating a health and safety hazard.  The removal of these high priority trees became the basis for the scope of this project.  The updated survey and tree removal plan was brought to the Safety and Facilities committees for review and comment over a period of several months.  These public meetings were attended by interested members of the local community and general public, including the designated representative of the Sherman Oaks Neighborhood Association.  The Facilities Committee approved the project plans and specifications identifying trees to be removed and pruned on March 3rd and March 31st.
	 
In preparation for the removal of the designated trees, and as required by the Environmental Impact Report, a Raptor Survey will also be performed prior to the start of the work in order to identify and protect any nesting birds from harm.
	 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website, advertised in local papers on May 14th, May 21st and published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to 7 local contractors capable of performing the work.  On June 17, 2014 bids were received on that design. Bids were received as follows:
	 
Bay Area Tree Service    $  54,600.00
Anderson Tree Care        $  59,880.00
Lewis Tree Service          $112,500.00
	 
Bay Area Tree Services was determined to be the lowest responsible bidder in the amount of $54,600.
	 
Therefore it is recommended to award a contract to Bay Area Tree Specialist in the amount of $54,600 for the Campus Site Improvement- Phase 1 Project.
	 
Budget Funding:
G-2010: $18,500- Removal of trees along Laswell Ave in conflict with new fencing.
SJCC: $36,100- Remaining project scope.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a construction contract, to Bay Area Tree Specialist for the Campus Site Improvement – Phase 1.

Upon further review of mechanical system design for the office areas of the South Campus Development Project at Evergreen Valley College, the District requested the new staff offices to have no more than three offices per Variable Air Volume (VAV) mechanical unit to improve the varying environmental conditions of the staff workplace.  As the design documents had already been submitted to DSA for review, this request required the Design Team to make numerous revisions to the documents including re-design of the mechanical ductwork and distribution, re-evaluation of the acoustics of the new design, and revisions to the mechanical schedules, energy model, and Title 24 calculations.

Gilbane and HMC Architects, with District and college representatives, have been working through a process to create District Standards and Campus Design Guidelines.  While compiling these Standards, an interest was expressed to understand the design advantages and cost impacts of LED lighting as compared to earlier standard fluorescent lighting.  It is suggested that the South Campus Development project be the test case for a life-cycle cost analysis (LCCA) service with energy modeling to quantify the system costs and energy reduction. 
	 
With the amount remaining in the HMC Agreement to develop the Design Standards, the scope of work to perfrom the LCCA can be included at no additional cost.  The Board is requested to approve the services to complete the LCCA and extend the District Standards schedule to accommodate the additional scope of work to August 29, 2014.

items.item_details:
Due to the timing of DSA final approval, Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) assembly timelines and scheduled Board meetings, the current project schedule is at risk due to the length of time required for these activities.  
	 
The ordering, fabrication and erection of structural steel for the South Campus Development project at Evergreen Valley College (EVC) is part of the project critical path (driving the project schedule).  The project team has identified the early release of structural steel detailing as an effective approach to protect the project schedule.  If the Board approves this approach, the contractor (Blach Construction) will be authorized to contract for detailing services related to structural steel at a value of $140,000.  While this will be a change to the Blach Construction Preconstruction Agreement, these costs are a normal part of the construction cost and are being advanced into the Preconstruction Agreement in order to protect approximately four weeks on the project schedule.  It is important to note that the ordering of steel members, the fabrication and the erection scopes of work will remain uncommitted until such time as the Board approves the GMP (anticipated to be its August 26, 2014 meeting).
	 
Because of this lengthened time for preconstruction, it is also necessary to extend the time of the Blach Preconstruction Agreement to compensate for the extended duration.  This Change Order #002 includes an add of $68,459 for staffing costs and adds 95 calendar days for Blach Construction preconstruction services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Pre-construction Change Order No. 002 to Blach Construction, Inc. in the amount of $208,459 for the release of structural steel detailing and to extend pre-construction phase services to November 3, 2014 for the South Campus Development Project at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On April 9, 2014 the Board agreed to enter into an agreement with Intermountain Electric Company to replace the existing pole mounted metal halide parking lot lights at both Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College with high efficiency LED light fixtures.   This agreement included a contract price of $698,900.00 with a substantial completion date of June 13, 2014.
	 
Schedule Extension - Lighting fixture arms ordered for the project were found to be too short for installation of 140 of the 266 lighting fixtures on the EVC campus.  The time needed to receive and install replacement fixture arms is equivalent to a time extension of 32 calendar days.
	 
Change Order No. 001 includes work that is the result of unforeseen conditions.
	 
1.  Troubleshoot SJCC Parking Garage Lights –    Add $380
After installing new LED lighting fixtures in the SJCC parking garage, the lighting fixtures would not stay on.  A photo cell is responsible for controlling the garage lighting.  In troubleshooting the issue the contractor found that, due to the additional brightness of fixtures in proximity to the photo cell, it was reacting by shutting off the system.  This change reimburses the contractor for the effort to discover and address the brightness issue.
	 
2.  Added neutral from lighting control panel to light pole circuits –     Add $3,217
During installation of the LED Lighting Fixture replacements at Evergreen Valley College, the contractor found an existing 480V wire had been mislabeled as a 277V wire.  Because the wiring is 480V, the Building Code requires the addition of a neutral wire to be connected at the lighting control panel and pulled to each pole on the circuit.
	 
The two items in this change order result in an ADD to the contract of $3,597.
	 
Original Contract Amount             $698,900
Previous Approved Changes        $           0
Change Order #010                      $    3,597
Total Contract and Changes        $ 702,497
	 
The total net change to Intermountain Electric’s contract as a result of all Change Orders is $3,597, which equates to 0.51% of the base contract.
	 
The Substantial Completion Date changes to July 15, 2014.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No.001, in the amount of $3,597.00 to Intermountain Electric Company and extend the substantial completion date to July 15, 2014 for the Evergreen Valley College (EVC) & San Jose City College (SJCC) LED Parking Lot Lighting Fixture Replacement Project.

items.item_details:
The Infrastructure Upgrade Project (39705) was created on November 12, 2013, when the Board of Trustees approved the split of the ERP Conversion Project (39704 - $10,000,000) into two equal parts of $5,000,000 each for the ERP Conversion Project and the Infrastructure Upgrade Project.  The scope of the Infrastructure Upgrade Project is to provide a âfault tolerant network and server environment to serve both Colleges and Workforce Institute from the District Office Data Center.â  The planning for the network and server environments is completed and the District is ready to proceed.  The first phase of the project will be the build-out of the 40 S. Market Data Center and associated Network, followed closely by projects at SJCC and EVC.
	 
On May 30, 2014, the District issued an RFP (RFP #G2010.0099 SJECCD IT Broker Integrator Infrastructure Services Partner) for broker/integrator services to supply the required hardware and implementation services to complete the build-out of the new data center and network design.  The RFP served to qualify vendors with significant manufacturer relationships and certifications, as well as identify local resources available to assist the District in long-term efforts to complete this significant infrastructure upgrade effort. It was unanimous among the evaluation committee members that Dasher Technologies provided the best solutions for the District.
	 
In order to proceed, the District seeks permission to negotiate a three-year master agreement with two optional one-year extensions with Dasher Technologies to provide the necessary hardware, design, integration and installation services on an on-going basis to provide continuity and consistency throughout the project. In addition, Dasher is a small, local, women owned business and has partnered with another small, local business for Data Center design and relocation.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees grant permission for staff to negotiate a Blanket Master Agreement with Dasher Technologies to provide a means to procure IT Broker Integrator Infrastructure Services for the District.

items.item_details:
When the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium JPA (JPA) was first formed, San Jose Evergreen Community College District (District) represented a majority of the FTES generated.  With the growth and maturation of the JPA, the District entered into a lease of real property in order to shift some of the responsibility for overhead.  Since its inception, the lease terms have fundamentally remained the same.  Discussions between the District and the JPA have been underway for some time to adjust the lease terms to better align with generally accepted industry standards, as well as to decrease the Districtâs overhead burden for the facilities the JPA currently occupies.  
	 
The lease term is for three years beginning July 1, 2013; terminating June 30, 2016.  
	 
Year One - FY2013/2014 - $100,000
Year Two - FY2014/2015 - $200,000
Year Three - FY2015/2016 - $300,000
	 
It is anticipated that the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium JPA will vacate the current location and relocate at the end of this lease agreement to clear the land for future development purposes.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the lease of real property between San Jose Evergreen Community College District and South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium JPA.

items.item_details:
On June 11, 2014, the Board approved the recommendation for allowing the District to enter into a contract with selected vendor(s) L. Luster & Associates and Enterprise Foundation immediately after successful negotiations of terms and the contract is finalized, and that a subsequent request for Board ratification was to be brought to the Tuesday, July 8, 2014 Board meeting to formally announce the selected vendors and dollar amount of the proposal (6.10.2014 Board Agenda Item F-10).  
	 
According to the Board-approved “Local Business Outreach Program for Minority-Owned Enterprise (MBE), Women-Owned Enterprise (WBE) and Small Business Outreach Plan" (9.13.2011 Board Agenda Item I-4), the District’s goal is to increase the contractor/vendor participation rate to 15 percent for diverse small businesses which include minority-owned, women-owned, and disabled veteran-owned businesses to do business with the District’s G-2010 bond and other non-bond projects and services.
	 
In response to the Request for Qualifications & Proposal G2010.0089 – Contractor Outreach Consulting Services with the due date of April 30, 2014 (http://www.sjeccd.edu/Bids/Pages/RFQ-G2010-0089-Contractor-Outreach-Consulting-SErvices.aspx), proposals from five strong teams were received.  Written proposals and interviews were evaluated by a well-respected diverse evaluation committee comprised of community leaders from the faith community, community-based organization, small business, corporate, staff, and multicultural leadership representatives.  The process was designed to be fair and thorough for all involved parties.  By consensus, the evaluation committee recommended two vendors, L. Luster & Associates (LLA) and Enterprise Foundation, for consideration and a possible collaboration having LLA as the lead consultant to achieve the District’s 15% outreach goal. 
	 
The District’s contract with L. Luster & Associates will yield significant impact on the District’s outreach efforts, both for the bond capital expenditures and in our daily operational spending.  LLA has demonstrated experience in assisting public agencies and private customers, including Alameda County, the City and County of San Francisco, and Kaiser Hospital in Redwood City.   The Enterprise Foundation is a coalition of many local and ethnically diverse chambers of commerce with a proven track record in developing and training small businesses to successfully compete for and perform contract work.  The Enterprise Foundation brings extensive database systems for identifying and tracking qualified businesses, as well as strong connections to the local minority and small business community.  These two teams together will bring organization, breadth of knowledge, clear communication and continuing relationships to our outreach efforts; we will see tangible, measurable results in terms of contract awards and contractor performance.
	 
The consulting services agreement includes the following components:
	 
Market research (identification and data collection) about local businesses and their readiness to perform work
Metrics development for measuring and evaluating our outreach efforts
Community outreach to introduce SJECCD to the region, make our business opportunities known, and build relationships with local businesses
Coaching, training, and preparation opportunities for local businesses, and
Project progress and results reporting, and recommendations for continuing improvement of the outreach program
	 
Each of these outreach services components will be developed collaboratively with District and Gilbane staff, but implemented by the consultant team. 
  
It is recommended that the Board ratify the attached contract between L. Luster & Associates, the lead organization for this collaborative between LLA and Enterprise Foundation, and the District in an amount not to exceed $311,845. items.item_details:
Background:
On February 12, 2013, the Board participated in a study session that addressed several key topics, including an overview of the board self-evaluation process that started in 2011, comparison of results for subsequent years and a recommendation on next steps.  It was agreed that the board should:
Create an updated work-plan based on recent findings
Use findings to identify opportunities for improvement
Build and expand on positive feedback; and,
Change from an annual review to a report every two years (next comprehensive evaluation to be conducted in 2015).
On March 14, 2014 three board members (Cruz, Ho and Fuentes) and three staff persons (Cepeda, Hawley and Breland) participated in the Governance Institute for Student Success (GISS) conducted by ACCT at Chabot College. The purpose of the Institute was to develop a strong Governance Policy for Student Success by providing an opportunity to: 
Conduct state-specific program to strengthen the governance of community and technical colleges and improve student success, equity, and completion; 
Convene  trustees and CEOs from community ant technical colleges to share and elevate knowledge of how effective governance contributes to a culture of transparency and accountability focused on improving student success, equity, and completion;
Assess institutional readiness on how to improve outcomes and how to gain political commitment to strengthen institutional capacity to accelerate an improve student success, equity and completion;
Enhance the trustees’ and CEOs role and responsibility in establishing policies, priorities, goals and practices that accelerate and improve students, success, equity and completion;
Promote advocacy for completion as key measure of college outcomes and student success.
   In preparation for the GISS institute, board members were asked to participate in a “Board Self-Assessment Survey” (https://www.surveymonkey.com/s/6F3KWRN). Only four of the seven board members completed the survey.  
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees establish an Ad Hoc Committee on Board Self-evaluation.  The charge of this committee is outlined on the attached document.

items.item_details:
The paradigm of the California community colleges has for the past five decades increasingly been one of inclusion for all populations, and both state and federal law call for California community colleges to provide services and programs to include students with disabilities and socioeconomic disadvantages. The student equity plan focus is a perfect alignment with the Extended Opportunity Programs & Services (EOPS) mission to increase access, course completion (retention/persistence), and basic skills completion, degrees, certificates and transfer for all low-income students and special student populations.[1] The EOPS programs at Evergreen Valley College and San José City College provide direct services to the student population as mandated under Student Equity Plan.  Title 5 regulations (title 5, §54220(d)) specify that SJECCD must review and address the need of the following populations when looking at disproportionate impact in student equity plans: American Indians or Alaskan natives, Asians or Pacific Islanders, Blacks, Hispanics, Whites, men, women, and persons with disabilities.[2]  The governor’s 2014-15 Budget proposed to target $100 million of additional Student Success and Support Program (SSSP) funding to close achievement gaps in access and success in underrepresented student groups, as identified in local student equity plans.  SB 852 (Leno), language specifies that the Chancellor’s Office shall allocate funds to districts “in a manner that ensures districts with a greater proportion or number of students who are high-need, as determined by the Chancellor’s Office, receive greater resources to provide services to these students.” [3]  Because students with disabilities and socioeconomic disadvantages are among the most vulnerable members of the population served by California community colleges, they are particularly dependent upon the scope and quality of programs for inclusion that facilitate their ability to obtain education in the California community colleges. The proposed state May 2014 Revised Budget elimination by the Governor's Office of partial restoration to the Extended Opportunity Programs and Services (EOPS) would dramatically impact the ability of these student service areas to address the increase needs of our student target community at SJECCD.
	 
It is, therefore, recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 070814-2 to restore SJCC & EVC programs to the 2007-2008 budget level using the Student Equity funds.
	 
	 
[1] California Community Colleges Student Equity Plan Fact Sheet; January 2014; http://extranet.cccco.edu/Divisions/StudentServices/StudentEquity.aspx
[2] California Community Colleges Student Equity Plan Fact Sheet; January 2014; http://extranet.cccco.edu/Divisions/StudentServices/StudentEquity.aspx
[3] California Community Colleges Student Equity Plan Fact Sheet; January 2014; http://extranet.cccco.edu/Divisions/StudentServices/StudentEquity.aspx

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets. This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
These revisions are the result of the application of a consistent process for the tracking and management of budget and expense related to the overall management of the Measure G-2010 Bond Program.  
	 
Projects 39905: Management and Related Costs and 39999: Election/Legal/EIR/ DO Labor and Related Costs are managed as separate projects in the Bond Program; however, the activities in these two projects benefit all active projects. By managing these activities as stand-alone projects during the year, the Districtâs bond management team is able to view and manage the budget and expenses that impact all projects in one location.  These costs are allowed to be distributed to projects for capitalization purposes.  The bond management team has determined that spreading the 39905: Management and Related Costs and 39999: Election/Legal/EIR/ DO Labor and Related Costs budget and associated expense to the active projects annually, as is allowed, provides a transparent view of the program.  
	 
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision #10 represents the transfer of budget, equal to the expense that will be spread to the individual projects through expense transfers prior to fiscal year close.  In this way, the budget balance remaining in 39905: Management and Related Costs and 39999:Election/Legal/EIR/ DO Labor and Related Costs at the end of the fiscal year will reflect what remains for future years, and the projects will capture the expenses attributed to them.

items.item_details:
On March 31, 2014 the EMC storage solution on the ERP production system reached end-of-life and no longer was supported by the vendor. This storage attaches to all of our ERP servers. On July 1, 2014 the current Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) server hardware reached end-of-life, which means that the manufacturer will no longer maintain and support the equipment. In January 2014, District staff began the process of locating an alternative service provider that could maintain the obsolete hardware. After several months of contacting vendors and searching for a solution, District staff located an option available through one of the District's current vendors, Computer Discount Warehouse (CDW), whereby they could sell maintenance on the District's end-of-life hardware via a competitively bid, piggybackable contract available through the National Joint Purchasing Alliance (NJPA). CDW has many government and higher education customers and the District Purchasing Department identified and validated the contract available for use through the NJPA: CDW-G Technology Solutions contract #111309-CDW.
The District requests authorization to award a contract in the amount of $122,569 to CDW for a one-year maintenance contract on our production ERP platform consisting of 11 HP Servers and an EMC storage solution.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award a contract in the amount of $122,569 to CDW for a one-year maintenance contract on our end-of-life production ERP platform consisting of 11 HP Servers and an EMC storage solution.

items.item_details:
INTRODUCTION
	 
Since March 2012, A. Plesica & Co., Gruen Gruen + Associates, Eller & Associates and staff with the San Jose Evergreen Community College District (the âteamâ), have completed market research, real estate financial analysis, land use planning and policy review and obtained consensus from the Board of Trustees of the San Jose Evergreen Community District on guiding principles for the disposition and development of an approximately 27-acre site adjoining Evergreen Valley College identified as not needed for the operations of the College. The team conducted meetings with a sub-committee of the Board of Trustees formed in order to review alternative property disposition and entitlement approaches and to review and approve the solicitation materials and process. Meetings were also held with the full Board of Trustees, which approved the issuance of the Request for Proposals.  
	 
Pre-proposal meetings were held with potential respondents. Four proposals were ultimately received. An initial report was prepared that described the proposed developments, business terms/conditions, present value of proposed ground rents, and advantages and disadvantages of each proposal. The team conducted discussions with the respondents and briefed the sub-committee on the evaluation of the proposals.
	 
At the direction of the sub-committee, the team conducted meetings with the development teams regarding requested clarifying/additional information about their respective proposals. Based on the additional information, an updated proposal evaluation report was prepared and a meeting with the full Board of Trustees was held to present the results of the evaluation and to obtain policy direction from the Board.
	 
PURPOSE 
	 
In light of the policy direction, the purpose of the meeting on July 8, 2014 is to provide an overview of the process to date and to describe the anticipated next steps to carry out the objectives of the disposition and development initiative to accomplish the goals of the Board of Trustees, including generating revenue to advance the educational mission of the District.

items.item_details:
The San Jose Evergreen Community College District self-operates two campus stores; one at each respective campus.  Over the past several years the campus stores have struggled to meet market demands and to provide exceptional service delivery to the District's students and faculty.  As a result the bookstores have not been able to remain profitable in a highly competitive and changing industry.  
	 
In an attempt to address this, the campus stores engaged Campus Bookstore Consulting Corporation (CBC) to conduct an assessment of the stores' operations.  This assessment was concluded in 2013 with a report issued on November 1, 2013.  The Executive Summary of this report is attached for reference.  In essence, the assessment provided six key initiatives: (1) improve availability of course materials; (2) protect course material market share; (3) reduce personnel expense ratio; (4) implement strategic marketing plan; (5) improve business planning; and (6) ensure adequate stock of general merchandise.  It was determined that the campus stores did not have the capacity to fully implement the initiatives.
	 
Board Policy 6900 states, "The campus bookstores shall be established and operated by the District and/or by a qualified vendor awarded a contract by competitive bid if found to be in the best interest of the District."  Accordingly, on February 28, 2014, the District issued Bid Proposal 14-0407 Management of the Campus Stores for SJECCD to ascertain if a qualified vendor has the capacity to meet market demands and to provide exceptional service delivery to the District's students and faculty.  The District received two proposals: (1) Barnes & Noble College; and (2) Follett Higher Education Group.  
	 
An evaluation committee comprised of a Purchasing Agent, a Bookstore Sales Associate, the Bookstore Supervisor, the Director of WIN/CalWORKS, the EOPS Counselor/Coordinator, and the Director of Fiscal Services assessed the proposals, received presentations from the potential vendors with CSEA Leadership in attendance, and visited the campus store at West Valley Mission (contracts with Barnes & Noble College) and the campus store at Ohlone College (contracts with Follett Higher Education Group).  The District also requested an analysis of the proposals be conducted by CBC given the highly technical nature of the engagement.  The analysis is attached for reference.  Highlights of the proposals are:
	 
Immediate implementation of a comprehensive textbook rental program, which will result in substantial savings to students.
Registration Integration:  students will have the ability to order course materials concurrently when they register.
Faculty Course Material Adoption:  faculty will have the ability to identify course materials via a portal with multiple options (e.g., adopt previous term's course material, adopt course material used by peers, read reviews on related course materials, search other course materials within the portal, etc.), along with access to a comprehensive database of textbook titles.
Provide an investment into the campus stores' facilities.
Provide an investment into the campus stores' technology.
Hire student workers on vendor's payroll while providing professional development opportunities to transition student workers to long-term employees including management employees.
Expanded product mix.
Establishment of campus-based bookstore "steering committees" to include input from students, faculty, and staff regarding bookstore issues, operations, and service.
Guarantee that every student registered in a class will have access to all course materials the first day of class.
Multiple Format Options (Digital, New, Used, Rental, Open Educational Resources).
Scholarships.
	 
The Evaluation Committee is recommending through the Chancellor that the Board of Trustees consider engaging Follett Higher Education Group to operate the two campus stores.  The proposed timeline is as follows:
	 
July 8, 2014:  Information Item presented the Board of Trustees.
August 26, 2014:  Action Item presented to the Board of Trustees awarding a five-year contract to Follett Higher Education Group to operate the two campus stores.
September 2014:  Develop Transition Plan.
October 2014:  Transition operation of the two campus stores.
Mr. Tom Byrne of Campus Bookstore Consulting will be available to answer any questions that the Board of Trustees may have.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Government Code Section 3547, the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District presents their Contract Proposal with the San Jose/Evergreen Federation of Teachers, AFT 6157 for 2014-2015.  The District requests that issues in the following articles be negotiated for 2014-2015.
	 
Article 4 Additional Faculty Member Rights – District has an interest in updating language associated with pay checks.
	 
Article's 8/9/10 – District has an interest in displaying compensation increments consistently throughout the Agreement.
	 
Article 9 Adjunct Faculty and Substitutes – District has an interest in addressing language associated with SRP, evaluations and step advancement.
	 
Article 10 Professional Recognition - District has an interest in addressing collegiate level courses, the appeals process, the sequencing of the article and others concerning clarifying language.
	 
Article 11 Working Days/Calendar - District has an interest in clarifying 11.5 and adjusting the alternate professional development plan.
	 
Article 12 Workload, Class size, Class Cancellation - District has an interest in addressing in on-line teaching, non-instructional assignments, faculty professional responsibilities and office hours.
	 
Article 13 Leaves and Absences - District has an interest in addressing FMLA revisions.
	 
Article 14 Sabbatical Leave - District has an interest in addressing multiple sabbaticals effect on small departments, compensation, and overload or extra work.
	 
Article 15 Overload - District has an interest in addressing overload assignments at home campus, deadlines for using banked overload
	 
Article 16 Transfers - District has an interest in addressing the processes associated with a self-initiated transfer.
	 
Article 19a – 22  Evaluations - District has an interest in addressing in each of these article language that addressees SLO assessment, criteria for evaluation, evaluation process, evaluation for online classes, evaluation committee, evaluation forms and on-line distribution and collection of student surveys.
	 
Article 23 Community Complaints- District has an interest in addressing the processes associated with student complaints and others.
	 
Article 24 – (New) Discipline and Compelling Circumstances - District has an interest in addressing discipline by articulating causes for discipline and the associated processes in its own article.
	 
Article 24 Reduction in Force– Current - District has an interest in renumbering 24 to 25 and clarify Faculty Service Areas and STRS calculation.
	 
Article 25 Day Care– Current –  District has an interest in deleting this article because it is no longer relevant.
	 
Article 32 Term – Affirm the length/duration of successor contract.
	 
The District reserves the right to add, amend, delete and/or change any of these proposals.
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Present the District's contract proposal for 2014-2015, and announcement of a public hearing to be conducted at the August 26, 2014 Board meeting.
